title: NFL playoff picture: How the Houston Texans clinched a playoff berth in Week 17
description: Texans. We break down how they can clinch a spot in the 2026 NFL Playoffs in Week 17.
fullText:
Game result: The Texans have punched their ticket into the 2026 NFL Playoffs. They beat the Chargers on Saturday 20-16 to clinch their playoff berth. They head into Sunday a half game back of the Jaguars in the AFC South. They need a Jaguars loss to have a chance at winning the division, but even if Jacksonville wins on Sunday, Houston remains alive for the division title heading into Week 18.

The Houston Texans can punch their playoff ticket this weekend.

After starting the season with a three-game losing streak and running their record to 3-5 over the first half of the season, Houston enters the penultimate weekend of the 2025 NFL campaign riding a seven-game winning streak, with a 10-5 record. That has Houston on the cusp of a playoff spot, which they can clinch this weekend.

Here is how the Texans can book their spot in the NFL Playoffs.

The Texans take on the Los Angeles Chargers, a team that has already clinched a playoff spot, at SoFi Stadium on Saturday afternoon. Houston will clinch a playoff spot with a win or a tie in that game.

Even if the Texans lose to the Chargers, they can still clinch a playoff spot on Sunday. Houston is in the playoffs if the Indianapolis Colts lose or tie against the Jacksonville Jaguars on Sunday.

Speaking of the Jaguars, while Jacksonville leads the AFC South the Texans are still alive for a division title. Houston would need to win their final two games, and get a loss from the Jaguars in one of their final two games, to move into the lead in the division.

Here are the current AFC standings following the Denver Broncos’ win over the Kansas City Chiefs on Christmas night:

New England Patriots (12-3) – x

Jacksonville Jaguars (11-4) – x

Los Angeles Chargers (11-4) – x

Here are the current AFC South standings:

Jacksonville Jaguars (11-4) – x

title: NFL playoff picture: What does Texans win over Chargers mean for AFC standings in Week 17
description: The Texans face the Chargers on Saturday. We break down what the game means for the NFL playoff picture in Week 17.
fullText:
Game result: The Texans beat the Chargers 20-16 on Saturday to clinch a playoff berth. They remain behind the Jaguars in the AFC South, but they cannot be eliminated from division contention if the Jaguars win on Sunday. The Chargers have already clinched a playoff berth, but the loss officially eliminates them from AFC West contention. They drop to the No. 7 seed and with Houston holding the tiebreaker over them, it’s unlikely they get much higher in the seeding.

Houston jumped out to a 14-0 lead in the first quarter and looked like they might cruise to victory. They never fell behind, but LA fought back and cut the lead to one possession late in the fourth quarter. Special teams miscues once again cost them in the loss. They cut the lead to 20-16 and then missed a field goal. They made a key illegal contact penalty on a third down sack and couldn’t get the ball back.

The Los Angeles Chargers have already clinched a playoff spot.

The Houston Texans can join them this weekend, starting when the two teams meet Saturday at SoFi Stadium.

Here is where both the Chargers and the Texans stand in the AFC playoff race.

For the Texans, 2025 has been a tale of two seasons. Houston began the year with three straight losses and went 3-5 over the first half of the season, but a seven-game winning streak has the Texans on the cusp of a playoff berth.

Houston will clinch a playoff spot with a win or a tie in that game against the Chargers.

However, even if the Texans lose to the Chargers, they can still clinch a playoff spot on Sunday. Houston is in the playoffs if the Indianapolis Colts lose or tie against the Jacksonville Jaguars on Sunday. And speaking of the Jaguars, Houston remains alive in the race for the AFC South title. With wins in their final two games and one loss from the Jaguars down the stretch, the Texans are AFC South champions.

As for the Chargers, they locked up a playoff spot when the Indianapolis Colts lost to the San Francisco 49ers on Monday Night Football.

But Los Angeles remains alive in the AFC West race. The Denver Broncos moved one step closer to claiming the division title on Christmas night with a win over the Kansas City Chiefs. But with a win over the Texans, the Chargers can wrap up the division title in Week 18, as they take on the Broncos in the final game of the season. A loss or a tie against Houston would eliminate the Chargers from the AFC West race.

Here are the current AFC standings following Denver’s win on Thursday night:

New England Patriots (12-3) – x

Jacksonville Jaguars (11-4) – x

Los Angeles Chargers (11-4) – x

This game could have an impact on seeding between the two teams, under the NFL’s tiebreaker formula. As you can see above, right now the Chargers are the No. 5 seed with an 11-4 record, but the Texans are 10-5, down in the No. 7 spot.

If Houston wins, the two teams would have matching 11-5 records. The Texans’ win would give them a tiebreaker advantage over the Chargers should they finish tied at the end of the season. However, if Houston, Los Angeles, and Buffalo all finish tied at the end of the year, then their respective conference records will be the determining factor. Entering Week 17, the Chargers have an 8-2 record in AFC games, as do the Texans, while Buffalo is 8-3.

title: NFL Playoff Picture 2025: Updated AFC and NFC standings, bracket, tiebreakers for Week 17
description: The Texans are in the playoffs, the Colts are out and the Broncos have won the AFC West.
fullText:
The Texans are in the playoffs, the Colts are out and the Broncos have won the AFC West. That's the result of the Texans' win over the Chargers on Saturday afternoon. Here's how the NFL playoff picture looks heading into Saturday night in Week 17:

1. Broncos (13-3) Clinched the AFC West, cosing in on the No. 1 seed in the AFC.

2. Patriots (12-3) Would lose the common-games tiebreaker to the Broncos.

3. Jaguars (11-4) The clear favorites in the AFC South.

4. Steelers (9-6) In the driver's seat in the AFC North.

5. Bills (11-4) Probably won't catch the Patriots in the AFC East, but they've clinched a playoff berth.

6. Texans (11-5) Clinched a playoff berth.

7. Chargers (11-5) Clinched a wild card, will likely rest starters in Week 18.

8. Colts (8-7) Mathematically eliminated.

9. Ravens (7-8) Their chances of catching the Steelers in the AFC North are slipping away.

10. Dolphins (6-9) Mathematically eliminated.

11. Chiefs (6-10) Mathematically eliminated.

12. Bengals (5-10) Mathematically eliminated.

13. Jets (3-12) Mathematically eliminated.

14. Titans (3-12) Mathematically eliminated.

15. Browns (3-12) Mathematically eliminated.

16. Raiders (2-13) Mathematically eliminated.

1. Seahawks (12-3) Beating the Rams gave them a leg up on the race for the No. 1 seed.

2. Bears (11-4) If the Bears win one more game or the Packers lose one more game, the Bears win the NFC North.

3. Eagles (10-5) Clinched the NFC East.

4. Panthers (8-7) In the driver's seat in the NFC South.

5. 49ers (11-4) Currently own the tiebreaker over the Rams thanks to a better record in the NFC West.

6. Rams (11-4) Losing to the Seahawks means they're likely to have to win three road games, instead of two home games, to reach the Super Bowl.

7. Packers (9-5-1) Clinched a playoff berth. Would need to win both their remaining games and have the Bears lose both their remaining games to win the NFC North.

8. Vikings (8-8) Mathematically eliminated.

9. Lions (8-8) Mathematically eliminated.

10. Buccaneers (7-8) Out of contention for a wild card, but they can still win the NFC South.

11. Cowboys (7-8-1) Mathematically eliminated.

12. Falcons (6-9) Mathematically eliminated.

13. Saints (5-10) Mathematically eliminated.

14. Commanders (4-12) Mathematically eliminated.

15. Cardinals (3-12) Mathematically eliminated.

16. Giants (2-13) Mathematically eliminated.

title: Westbrook passes Magic Johnson for 7th place in career assists as Kings beat Mavericks 113-107
description: Russell Westbrook scored 21 points and moved past Magic Johnson for seventh place on the NBA’s career assists list while leading the Sacramento Kings to a 113-107 win over the Dallas Mavericks on Saturday.  Westbrook grabbed five rebounds, and his nine assists gave him 10,149 — eight more than Johnson.  The 37-year-old Westbroook also moved within nine points of tying Dominique Wilkins for 19th on the NBA’s scoring chart while propelling Sacramento to its third victory in 13 games.
fullText:
SACRAMENTO, Calif. (AP) — Russell Westbrook scored 21 points and moved past Magic Johnson for seventh place on the NBA’s career assists list while leading the Sacramento Kings to a 113-107 win over the Dallas Mavericks on Saturday.

Westbrook grabbed five rebounds, and his nine assists gave him 10,149 — eight more than Johnson.

The 37-year-old Westbroook also moved within nine points of tying Dominique Wilkins for 19th on the NBA’s scoring chart while propelling Sacramento to its third victory in 13 games.

Dallas got within 111-107 with nine seconds remaining before DeMar DeRozan made two free throws to seal it.

Keon Ellis hit five 3-pointers and had 21 points, Maxime Raynaud added 19 points and Dennis Schroder scored 10. Rookie guard Nique Clifford had eight points and nine rebounds off the bench to help the Kings (8-23) to their fourth consecutive win over the Mavericks.

Cooper Flagg had 23 points, six rebounds and five assists but also committed five turnovers for Dallas (12-21). P.J. Washington had 17 points and four blocks, and Klay Thompson scored 14 points.

The Mavs have lost four of five.

After blowing much of an 18-point lead, Sacramento made four 3-pointers as part of a 20-10 run in the third quarter. Ellis drained two 3s and scored eight points as part of the surge.

The Kings are 35-48 under coach Doug Christie, who took over initially on an interim basis when Mike Brown was fired last December.

Ellis got the Kings going early with 13 points in the first quarter to help Sacramento to a double-digit lead.

Dallas trimmed the margin to eight but the Kings doubled that midway through the second quarter and led 59-44 at halftime.

Mavericks: Visit the Portland Trail Blazers on Monday night.

Kings: Play the Lakers in Los Angeles on Sunday.

title: Broncos clinch first AFC West title since 2015
description: Following the Chargers' loss to the Texans, the Broncos have clinched their first AFC West title since 2015.
fullText:
The Denver Broncos (13-3) have clinched an AFC West title after the Los Angeles Chargers (11-5) lost to the Houston Texans (11-5) on Saturday evening.

Now, even if the Broncos lose to the Chargers in Week 18, Denver will be the division champion and won't be lower than the fourth seed in the AFC's playoff picture. The Broncos are currently the No. 1 seed in the conference.

Denver would clinch the top seed with a win against L.A. next week. Or, even if the Broncos lose, they would still clinch the top spot with losses from the New England Patriots (12-3), Jacksonville Jaguars (11-4) and Buffalo Bills (11-4) on Sunday.

This marks the first time since 2015 that Denver has won the AFC West. The Broncos went 12–4 that season and went on to win Super Bowl 50. The Kansas City Chiefs then won nine straight division titles before being swept by Denver and missing the playoffs in 2025.

Social: Follow Broncos Wire on Facebook and Twitter/X! Did you know: These 25 celebrities are Broncos fans.

This article originally appeared on Broncos Wire: NFL news: Broncos clinch AFC West, top four seed in playoffs

title: Chargers fall short in loss vs. Texans
description: The Los Angeles Chargers couldn’t beat the Houston Texans in Week 17.
fullText:
The Los Angeles Chargers saw their winning streak snapped by the hands of the Houston Texans in a 20-16 loss at SoFi Stadium in Week 17.

The Chargers started the game off on the wrong foot, allowing two Texans touchdowns on the first two drives, conceding a 14-0 deficit right off the bat. The Chargers tried to catch up but missed cues that included an interception thrown in the red zone and a missed field goal right before halftime did the Chargers in.

Chargers quarterback Justin Herbert completed 21 of 32 passes for 236 yards and a touchdown, while Omarion Hampton had a touchdown on the ground.

The loss for the Chargers means that Denver Broncos have won the AFC West. Next week’s matchup is simply for playoff positioning and not the division title.

The Chargers will be wild cards for the second year in a row and the Texans now have the tiebreaker on them if they have the same record.

title: Colts eliminated from playoff contention with Texans' Week 17 win
description: The Indianapolis Colts have been eliminated from playoff contention following the Houston Texans' Week 17 win.
fullText:
The Indianapolis Colts have been eliminated from playoff contention.

In order for the Colts' playoff hopes to remain alive going into the final week of the season, Indianapolis needed a victory over Jacksonville coupled with a Houston Texans' loss.

However, the Texans would defeat the LA Chargers on Saturday night by a score of X to X. The Texans now have 11 wins this season.

The Colts are 8-7 on the year and have lost five consecutive games and six of their last seven games dating back to before their bye week.

This is now the fifth consecutive season that the Colts have missed the postseason. Their last appearance came in 2020.

This is the fourth-longest playoff drought in the NFL, according to Kevin Bowen.

In addition to that, the Colts also haven't won the AFC South title since 2014. Jacksonville, Houston, and Tennessee have each won the division at least twice during that span.

Injuries were certainly part of the equation in the Colts' second-half struggles, but, as noted, the outcome this season is all too familiar for Indianapolis and GM Chris Ballard.

The Colts will enter the offseason with question marks around the quarterback position and unknowns about what the future holds for Ballard and potentially head coach Shane Steichen.

This article originally appeared on Colts Wire: NFL playoff standings: Indianapolis Colts eliminated after Texans win

title: NFL salary cap 2026: Indianapolis Colts highest paid players, salary cap hits in 2026
description: Here are the Indianapolis Colts' highest-paid players for the 2026 NFL season. What is the 2026 NFL salary cap?
fullText:
The Indianapolis Colts (8-7) have been eliminated from AFC playoff contention. They won seven of their first eight games before the schedule toughened, quarterback Daniel Jones suffered two injuries and the defense sometimes struggled late.

Here are the 10 players who will count the most toward their 2026 salary cap — which won't be known until the spring but is project to be in the $304 million range.

(2026 salary cap hit, per Spotrac, with final season of current contract)

2026 salary, final year of current contract: $29 million, 2026

2025 performance: The sixth-year veteran led the Colts with 76 catches and 7 receiving touchdowns through 15 games. He averaged 10 yards per catch. He had 9 receptions in a game twice.

2026 salary, final year of current contract: $26.6 million, 2026

2025 performance: The 10th-year veteran has missed five games with a neck injury and was placed on season-ending IR; it's the second straight season he missed at least five games. Through 15 weeks, he had 27 tackles 4 sacks and 13 quarterback hits.

2026 salary, final year of current contract: $24.2 million, 2026

2025 performance: Another year, another Pro Bowl. The left guard has been so honored in all eight seasons, and he has been an All-Pro three times.

2026 salary, final year of current contract: $20.2 million, 2027

2025 performance: The 8th-year player signed for 3 years up to $54 million in the offseason. However, his 2025 was interrupted three times by concussions. He appeared in 7 games with 25 tackles, 7 passes defended and a fumble recovery.

2026 salary, final year of current contract: $17.5 million, 2029

2025 performance: The 2022 3rd-round draft by the Colts helped Quenton Nelson anchor the left side of the offensive line before an elbow injury knocked him out for a game.

2026 salary, final year of current contract: $15.6 million, 2026

2025 performance: The 6th-year player was in the NFL MVP conversation after scoring 3 touchdowns in a game 5 times in the Colts' first 10 games. As the Colts faded late, so did Taylor, averaging 70 rushing yards and scoring 2 total TDs in a late 5-game stretch.

2026 salary, final year of current contract: $15 million, 2028

2025 performance: In his first season with the Colts, the 5th-year player led them with 4 interceptions and 8 passes defended through 15 games. He also had 72 tackles.

2026 salary, final year of current contract: $14.3 million, 2026

2025 performance: The 9th-year player had 49 tackles, 5 quarterback hits, 1/2 sack and 1 interception through 15 games.

2026 salary, final year of current contract: $13.2 million, 2026

2025 performance: The 9th-year player had 44 tackles, an interception returned for a touchdown and 6 passes defended through 15 games.

2026 salary, final year of current contract: $10.8 million, 2027

2025 performance: The No. 4 overall pick of the 2023 draft appeared in 2 games before suffering an eye injury in a freak accident during pregame warmups in Week 6. Fun fact: Richardson had 1 completion in 2025 — to himself, for a 9-yard gain.

(The team-specific numbers will change with each transaction)

NFL 2026 projected salary cap, per Spotrac: $304.3 million

Colts 2026 salary cap space available: $53.9 million, 11th most

Colts active salaries for 2026: $249.6 million

Colts 2026 dead cap: $2 million

Joel A. Erickson and Nathan Brown cover the Colts all season. Get more coverage on IndyStarTV and with the Colts Insider newsletter.

This article originally appeared on Indianapolis Star: NFL salary cap 2026: Indianapolis Colts salary cap hits, highest paid players

title: Current NFL playoff matchups for the 2025 NFL postseason
description: The NFL playoff bracket is coming into focus and we have the up-to-date matchups \.
fullText:
We are nearing the end of the 2025 NFL season and the playoff picture is coming into focus. With that comes the matchups that will be set soon and the playoff opponents for each team.

As we enter Week 17, the results of these games will shift who plays who, and we will track that all here.

The number one see gets a first-round bye and home-field advantage through the playoffs.

Entering Week 17, the Denver Broncos have a chance to clinch the number one seed but it’s going to take a lot of work. It is likely to stretch to Week 18.

Pittsburgh can clinch the four seed with a win OR a Ravens loss.

2. New England Patriots (12-3)* host 7. Los Angeles Chargers (11-5)*
3. Jacksonville Jaguars (11-4)* host 6. Houston Texans (11-5)*
4. Pittsburgh Steelers (9-6) host 5. Buffalo Bills (11-4)*

The NFC bracket is wide open entering Week 17, but the Seahawks can clinch the one seed with a win and some NFC West help.

The Carolina Panthers can clinch the four seed with a win and a Buccaneers loss.

2. Chicago Bears (11-4)* host 7. Green Bay Packers (9-5-1)
3. Philadelphia Eagles (10-5)** host 6. Los Angeles Rams (11-4)*
4. Carolina Panthers (8-7) host 5. San Francisco 49ers (11-4)*

*: Clinched playoff berth
**: Clinched division title
***: Clinched no. 1 seed

Saturday 4:30 p.m. result: The Texans beat the Chargers 20-16 to punch their ticket to the playoffs and keep their AFC South hopes alive. They cannot be eliminated from division contention this week if the Jaguars win on Sunday. The result also secured the AFC West title for the Broncos and leaves open the door for the Broncos to clinch the No. 1 seed. Denver is guaranteed can clinch home field through the AFC bracket if the Patriots, Jaguars, and Bills all lose on Sunday.

Christmas 8:30 p.m. result: Denver’s win moved the Broncos one step closer to locking up the AFC West, and perhaps the No. 1 seed in the conference. Denver can clinch the AFC West on Saturday if the Chargers lose or tie against the Houston Texans. The Broncos can also clinch the No. 1 seed in the conference this weekend, but they will need a lot of help to accomplish that goal. Denver locks up the No. 1 seed with a Patriots loss to the Jets, a Chargers loss or tie to the Texans, a Jaguars loss or tie against the Colts, and a Bills loss or tie against the Eagles.

Christmas 4:30 p.m. result: The Lions lost to the Vikings, which officially clinched a berth for the Packers and eliminated the Lions. That solidifies all but one team in the playoff field. The Packers currently hold the final wild card berth, but still have an outside shot at the NFC North title. The seeding is not set for the six teams already in the field. The final team to join the field will be the NFC South champion, and that team is all but certain to be the No. 4 seed.

We will update as more Week 17 results come in.

title: Saturday Football Week 17: Ravens at Packers – Live Discussion
description: The Green Bay Packers are just 2.5-point road favorites over the Baltimore Ravens at home in Week 17.
fullText:
The Green Bay Packers are locked into their playoff spot at home against the Baltimore Ravens, so they are not too worried about wins and losses choosing to get Jordan Love fully healthy before the playoffs begin. Technically, the Ravens are still in the playoff hunt, but that would end with a Pittsburgh Steelers victory on Sunday.

Kickoff is set forp.m. Mile High time at Lambeau Field in Green Bay, Wisconsin and will air on NBC.

According to FanDuel, the Packers are favored by just 2.5-points over the Ravens. That surprised me until I realized Love was out of the game. The Ravens need to win to keep their playoff hopes alive, so I am going to give them the benefit of doubt here that they’ll find a way to win to keep the pressure on Aaron Rodgers and the Steelers come Sunday.

Prediction: Ravens 27, Packers 20.

title: Texans win eliminates Colts from 2025 playoffs; what derailed a promising season
description: A once-promising Colts season that included a 7-1 start, has ended without a postseason berth, sparked by a historic late-season collapse.
fullText:
The Colts’ season has come to an all too familiar ending for a fifth consecutive year. But in 2025, an Indianapolis franchise led by general manager Chris Ballard and head coach Shane Steichen did so in historic fashion.

With two games left to play, Indianapolis – once holder of the best record in the NFL at 7-1 – has been eliminated from the playoffs by Houston’s 20-16 road win over the Chargers on Saturday.

Entering Week 17, the Texans held a two-game lead on the Colts for the AFC’s final wild card playoff spot. In order to snap a four-year postseason drought, the Colts needed their AFC South divisional foes to lose out, combined with winning out themselves and getting help elsewhere around the league to avoid a historic collapse.

With Saturday’s result, the Colts become just the sixth team since the AFL-NFL merger in 1970 to miss the playoffs after starting 7-1. Three of those previous teams – the 1975 Dolphins, the 1987 Chargers and the 1988 Saints – missed out when the NFL’s playoff format only included four (Dolphins) or five (Chargers and Saints) teams from each conference.

Houston started 0-3 and will be the first team since the 2018 Texans (and second since 1999) to make the playoffs after that start since the AFL-NFL merger. Teams were 245 of the 252 teams to start 0-3 missed the playoffs in that timeframe.

Here are the eight biggest factors that led to the Colts missing the playoffs for the fifth straight season – a postseason-less campaign brought on by a skid that will go down in the NFL’s history books.

The overarching theme to the Colts’ hot-and-cold season through Week 16 has been the team’s struggle to beat playoff-caliber teams consistently or win high-pressure games down the stretch. Following the team’s come-from-behind home win in Week 2 over a Broncos squad that could land the No. 1 seed in the AFC, the Colts have gone just 1-6 against teams that have clinched a playoff spot or are still in the running.

The Colts started 2-1 in such games – including a resounding road win, 38-24, over the Chargers – but also lost in Week 4 on the road to the Rams and in Week 9 in Pittsburgh. The Colts’ six losses against playoff-caliber teams this year have seen the offense that was once considered historically dynamic score just a tick under 20 points per game.

The Colts are also 3-5 in one-score game this year, including wins against the lowly Cardinals (31-27) and Falcons (31-25).

The beginning of the end came near the end of the first quarter in Jacksonville when starting quarterback Daniel Jones planted his foot awkwardly and fell to the ground untouched as he released the ball. Instantly, Jones grasped for his lower right leg, unstrapped his helmet, yanked it off and slammed it to the ground. He’d suffered a torn Achilles tendon, an injury with an unprecise recovery timeline famous for taking away a player’s explosiveness for a season after the injury – doubly concerning for a quarterback who signed with the Colts this offseason on a one-year deal.

Jones’ torn Achilles forced the Colts to think outside the box and look to Philip Rivers, a quarterback who last led the Colts to the playoffs in 2020, but who retired after that season and had been coaching high school football and training draft prospects in the half-decade since.

For a 44-year-old off-the-couch quarterback, Rivers’ performance has been commendable, including throwing for 277 yards and two touchdowns Monday night in a game largely lost by a woeful defensive performance. His 120-yard, one-touchdown performance in Week 15 helped manage the game and was about as good as the Colts could’ve hoped for.

There’s reason to think a healthy Jones quarterbacks the Colts to at least two or three wins during the team’s five-game losing streak.

Now, the Colts’ quarterback questions that have persisted since Andrew Luck retired more than six years ago, will continue.

The Colts’ cornerback injury woes began in training camp with rookie third-round pick Justin Walley – who looked primed to start – went down with a torn ACL during a joint practice.

The Colts released third-year corner JuJu Brents, a 2023 second-round pick, after Brents struggled with a hamstring injury. The team’s former starter, 2023 seventh-round pick Jaylon Jones, also had hamstring issues throughout the summer and again in Week 1, sidelining him until early-November.

The Colts were forced to look outside the organization late in the summer to fill a key spot alongside major offseason signing Charvarius Ward, an All-Pro corner signed to a three-year deal in the spring. Four games into a return to the field, however, former Dolphins corner Xavien Howard retired after he was targeted and exploited routinely against the Broncos and Rams.

The Colts – plagued further by injury as Ward missed six of the team’s first 10 games due to a series of concussions – were forced to return to a combination of Mekhi Blackmon, acquired from the Vikings for a sixth-round pick in the preseason, undrafted rookie Jonathan Edwards and Cameron Mitchell, added to the practice squad in October.

The team traded for All-Pro corner Sauce Gardner at the deadline for two first-round picks and receiver Adonai Mitchell, but Gardner would play just two full games with Indianapolis before a calf injury two plays into a Week 13 game against Houston. Thinking they’d locked down the best corner tandem in the league for the stretch run, the Colts saw Ward and Gardner share the field for a single game. By the time Gardner returned to practice this week, Ward had been lost for the year with his third concussion.

The Colts secondary has given up the second-most passing yards per game in the league this year (250.7) while it's tied for 21st in yards gained per pass attempt allowed (7.2) and tied for 22nd in yards per completion allowed (11.2).

Though he's second in the league in rushing yards in 2025, what was once on pace to be a historic 2025 campaign for Colts running back Jonathan Taylor has turned far more pedestrian of late.

Since the Colts’ Week 11 bye – which followed Taylor’s 244 rushing yards and three touchdowns in Berlin against the Falcons – the Colts’ tailback has just 350 yards in five games while averaging a paltry 3.5 yards per carry. Taylor was averaging 6.0 yards per rush at the season’s halfway mark.

What’s worse is Indianapolis’ run game has lost its explosiveness . Before the Colts’ bye, significant chunks of Taylor’s 1,139 rushing yards had come off “explosive runs” – carries of 10 yards or longer, which the sixth-year back was achieving nearly 15% of the time.

In the five games – and 99 carries – since, Taylor has just eight such carries, with only one of them even hitting 15 yards (an early-game 27-yard carry against the Chiefs). In only one game since the Colts’ bye has Taylor even averaged 4.0 yards per carry (on 21 carries for 85 yards against the Texans), and he picked up just 2.9 yads per carry on Monday against the 49ers – one of the 10 worst games of his career.

DeForest Buckner, a captain for the Colts and the soul of its defense, missed five games due to a herniated disc in his neck and a compressed nerve suffered in the Colts’ Week 9 loss in Pittsburgh. The Colts went 1-4 during his absence, which corresponded with a downturn in the defense’s ability to put pressure on the quarterback and defend the run.

In the five games Buckner missed, the Colts defense registered just 10 sacks – seven coming against the Falcons and Chiefs. Of those 10 sacks, four have been by linebackers or safeties. A defense that with Buckner ranked top 6 in sacks is now tied for 13th, a slip due to offenses no longer having to double Buckner and an Indianapolis defense line often incapable of winning one-on-one battles.

During the Colts’ time without Bucker, the Colts defense also gave up 109.8 yards per game on the ground, a figure that would rank 14th-best over the course of the season. Before he was sidelined, the Colts were one of the best run-stopping units in the league.

Backup quarterback Anthony Richardson fractured his orbital bone after he was struck in the face by an apparatus that snapped after the third-year quarterback had attached a stretching band to it in the locker room to begin his pre-game warmups ahead of the Colts’ Week 6 home game against the Cardinals. He required surgery and only returned to practice ahead of the team’s Week 16 game against the 49ers.

But Richardson has vision issues that have kept the Colts coaching staff and front office from returning him to the active roster.

When Jones went down one quarter into the game in Jacksonville, the Colts were forced to look to rookie sixth-round pick Riley Leonard. He played the first meaningful snaps of his NFL career that afternoon in rain and at a stadium the Colts had not won at in a decade. His performance was valiant – 18-for-29 for 145 yards, an interception and a rushing score – but it wasn’t enough in a 36-19 rout.

It’s no guarantee having Richardson would’ve guaranteed a win. But having a dynamic, experienced quarterback under center in Jacksonville could’ve brought a bit of a spark, and not needing to ground-and-pound in the same manner in Seattle with Rivers might’ve led to just enough offense to tack on another win in 2025.

In what had already been a rocky, up-and-down tenure with the Colts, Adonai Mitchell didn't hold onto the football through the goal line on a runaway touchdown catch-and-run against the Rams.

Down three in the second half of the Week 4 game with the Rams, Mitchell was on the final steps of a career-play – what should’ve been a 76-yard touchdown. Instead, the ball slipped out of his fingertips as he attempted to change hands as he prepared to cross the goal line. The ball rolled through the back of the end zone and was instead ruled a 75-yard catch, fumble and touchback.

Instead of going up four points early in the third quarter, the Colts defense stumbled to the finish, giving up a pair of touchdowns in the final four minutes to lose 27-20 against a team that now has an argument as one of the best in the league.

Had Mitchell not dropped that ball, there’s a real chance the Colts could’ve started 8-0 and come out of their Week 11 bye 9-1. It doesn’t mean they’d be sitting any better than 9-6 at this point, but at minimum, the Colts could’ve still had a chance to keep their playoff hopes alive in Week 17 with a potential win-and-in Week 18 matchup in Houston.

Three plays later, the Colts were across midfield, and within four plays – and with just over 2:30 left on the clock – Indianapolis sat on the Houston 32 with 1st and 10. A one-yard run and a pair of incomplete passes later, the home squad faced 4th-and-long on the 31. Had Badgley connected on his earlier extra point, the Colts could’ve lined him up and attempted a 49-yard game-tying field goal.

That missed PAT, instead, required a touchdown, with an incomplete pass turned the ball over on downs. It was Badgley's third missed PAT in his seven games with the Colts and Badgley was waived the next day.

Joel A. Erickson and Nathan Brown cover the Colts all season. Get more coverage on IndyStarTV and with the Colts Insider newsletter.

title: Lamar Jackson injury history: A complete timeline of injuries for Ravens QB
description: Lamar Jackson is one of the NFL's most electrifying players when healthy, but nagging injuries have followed him throughout his career.
fullText:
Lamar Jackson injury history: A complete timeline of injuries for Ravens QB originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

There is no doubt Baltimore Ravens QB Lamar Jackson is one of the most electrifying players in the NFL when healthy, but keeping him 100% healthy has been a challenge at times.

Between MVP campaigns in 2019 and 2023, Jackson ended two seasons on the sidelines due to injury, and 2025 quickly began to get away from the Ravens when another injury struck.

It’s likely no coincidence Jackson’s fully healthy seasons have been far and away his best. After recovering from injury in 2022, Jackson returned to MVP form, winning his second MVP award in 2023 before putting together an even more impressive campaign the following season from a statistical standpoint.

Here’s a look back at Jackson’s injury history and how many games he has missed due to injury.

MORE:Explaining the Lamar Jackson trade rumors

After missing one game for a pre-playoff break in 2019 and another due to COVID-19 in 2020, Jackson missed his first games because of injury in 2021.

While a non-COVID illness initially cost him a game against the Chicago Bears in 2021, Jackson went on to miss the Ravens’ final four games of the season with a significant ankle sprain. He suffered the injury early in a loss to the Cleveland Browns in Week 14, and Baltimore limped to an 0-5 finish and missed the playoffs with Jackson out of the mix.

Jackson struggled to match his MVP production in 2022, throwing 10 touchdowns over his first three starts but just seven over his final nine before going down with a sprained PCL in his knee.

Despite being labeled week to week and hoping for a playoff return, Jackson missed the final five games of the regular season and the Ravens’ wild-card matchup with the Cincinnati Bengals. Baltimore went 3-3 without Jackson, including a playoff loss, and some wondered whether he had played his last down as a Raven with his contract set to expire after the season.

After plenty of speculation about his future, Jackson agreed to a five-year, $260 million contract extension to remain in Baltimore long term.

MORE:Inside Lamar Jackson's family tree

Jackson suffered a hamstring injury against the Kansas City Chiefs in Week 4 of the 2025 season and didn't return for a month, missing games against the Houston Texans, Los Angeles Rams and Chicago Bears with a bye week sandwiched in-between.

The injury cost Jackson a bit longer than he hoped, as the Bears game had been targeted by the Ravens as his potential return date, but he looked every bit like himself in his return against the Miami Dolphins. Unfortunately for Jackson, that momentum did not last.

After returning from a hamstring injury, Jackson struggled to play anything like he did in 2024, throwing four touchdowns and five interceptions across seven starts following his return against the Dolphins.

In the meantime, Jackson battled various ailments that kept him out of practices. Jackson missed practice time with injuries to his ankle, toe and knee, also missing a practice due to illness. While those injuries never kept him out of a game, his performance appeared to be impacted by them.

Jackson exited a prime-time game against the New England Patriots with a back contusion and did not return. He was summarily ruled out of the Ravens’ Week 17 game against the Packers. While Jackson did not receive a formal diagnosis beyond a “deep tissue bruise,” the injury was painful enough that he could not return to a pivotal game against an AFC contender.

MORE: Where does Lamar Jackson rank among the 13 greatest Ravens of all time?

Before his back contusion deep into the 2025 season, Jackson missed 17 games over eight NFL seasons, including the playoffs. Here is the complete breakdown:

Jackson's 17 missed games include two due to pre-playoffs rest and two due to illness. His longest injury-related absence spanned six games, as Jackson missed the Ravens' final five regular season games and a playoff game with a sprained PCL in his knee in 2022.

title: Denver Broncos are your 2025 AFC West Champions
description: The Denver Broncos are your 2025 AFC West Champions for the first time since 2015. On Christmas Night, the Denver Broncos defeated the Kansas City Chiefs and improved to 13-3 on the year and set themselves up with a chance to clinch the AFC West on Saturday with a Chargers loss. Well, the Texans took […]
fullText:
The Denver Broncos are your 2025 AFC West Champions for the first time since 2015.

On Christmas Night, the Denver Broncos defeated the Kansas City Chiefs and improved to 13-3 on the year and set themselves up with a chance to clinch the AFC West on Saturday with a Chargers loss. Well, the Texans took care of business today and defeated the Chargers, which has clinched the AFC West for the Denver Broncos.

AFC WEST CHAMPS.

Goal No. 1 ✅

And we’re still climbing. pic.twitter.com/yHbSmyw8Ww

— Denver Broncos (@Broncos) December 28, 2025

This is the Broncos’ 16th AFC West Championship, their first since 2015, and the first for Head Coach Sean Payton and quarterback Bo Nix.

The Broncos have been on a magical run this season, and after starting the season 1-2, they ripped off 11 straight wins and are now AFC West champions and the favorites for the number one seed in the AFC. They have been led by their elite defense and second-year quarterback Bo Nix, who has improved as the season went on and has led multiple 4th quarter comebacks and game-winning drives.

With a postseason berth and now the AFC West locked up, the Broncos will set their sights on the number one seed in the AFC. They can clinch the one seed as early as tomorrow, but they will need a lot of help for that to happen. They will need the Patriots to lose to the Jets, the Bills to lose to the Eagles, and the Jaguars to lose to Grandpa Phillip Rivers and the Colts. All three of those scenarios playing out tomorrow are highly unlikely, so the Broncos will likely need to win next weekend, at Mile High, vs. the Chargers.

The Broncos are back where they belong. Three years ago, the team fired Nathaniel Hackett the day after Christmas and just signed quarterback Russell Wilson to a contract that would age poorly. Now, three years later. Sean Payton has led the Broncos back to being Super Bowl contenders, and Bo Nix is your franchise quarterback.

TIME TO CELEBRATE BRONCOS COUNTRY, THE DENVER BRONCOS ARE YOUR 2025 AFC WEST CHAMPIONS!

title: NFL playoff picture: How the Jacksonville Jaguars can clinch the AFC South title in Week 17
description: The Jacksonville Jaguars have punched their ticket to the 2026 NFL Playoffs, but they also can clinch the division. We break down how they can clinch the AFC South in the 2026 NFL Playoffs in Week 17.
fullText:
Saturday result: The Jaguars will not be able to clinch the AFC South in Week 17. The Houston Texans beat the Los Angeles Chargers on Saturday, which precludes Jacksonville from clinching the division title on Sunday if they beat the Colts. However, a win over Indianapolis would leave Jacksonville in first place holding a one game lead over Houston heading into Week 18.

The Jacksonville Jaguars clinched a playoff berth this past week, but can clinch something more important in Week 17. They are in control of their fate in the AFC South and clinch the division title as soon as this week. They need a win and some help from their Houston division-mates.

The Jaguars face the Indianapolis Colts on Sunday and are 5.5-point favorites. Jacksonville will be without right guard Patrick Mekari due to a back injury, while center Robert Hainsey is questionable with a groin injury. The Colts will be without center Tanor Bortolini (concussion) and defensive tackle DeForest Buckner (back). Their list of questionable players includes cornerback Sauce Gardner (calf) and right guard Dalton Tucker (shoulder).

If the Jaguars clinch the AFC South, it would be their first playoff appearance and division title since 2022. That year, they beat the Chargers in the Wild Card round and then lost to the Chiefs in the Divisional Round. They have won their division four times prior to this sesason.

The Jaguars can clinch the AFC South with a win and a Texans loss or tie against the Chargers on Saturday. Houston is traveling to LA for the game and is a 1.5-point underdog.

title: No. 24 Georgia Tech falls to No. 12 BYU, 21-25, at Pop-Tarts Bowl
description: Georgia Tech (9-4) had a chance to tie the game when senior quarterback Haynes King found Eric Rivers down the sideline with a 66-yard pass on fourth-and-15 to the BYU 18-yard line with 35 seconds to play.
fullText:
Jovesa Damuni scored on a 4-yard run with two minutes remaining and No. 12 BYU rallied from an 11-point deficit in the second half for a 25-21 win over No. 24 Georgia Tech on Saturday in the Pop-Tarts Bowl.

Damuni’s scoring run capped a nine-play, 70 drive by the Cougars (12-2), who were led by freshman quarterback Bear Bachmeier. Bachmeier passed for 57 yards in the drive.

Bachmeier was 27 for 38 passing for 325 yards with a touchdown and an interception as the Cougars piled up 426 total yards. It was the freshman’s third 300-yard passing game of the season.

Georgia Tech (9-4) had a chance to tie the game when senior quarterback Haynes King found Eric Rivers down the sideline with a 66-yard pass on fourth-and-15 to the BYU 18-yard line with 35 seconds to play. Facing fourth down, King threw to the end zone for Jamal Haynes, but BYU’s Evan Johnson intercepted the pass in the end zone to secure the victory.

King was 23 for 41 passing for 254 yards, two touchdowns and the game-ending interception.

The Cougars fell 11 points behind due to a 10-second scoring binge by the Yellow Jackets.

Georgia Tech took a 14-10 lead on a King pass to Rivers with 5:28 to play in the first half. Cody Hagen muffed the ensuing kickoff and the Yellow Jackets recovered the fumble. One play later, King found tight end J.T. Byrne for a 6ix-yard TD pass.

The game was defined by red zone troubles.

BYU took the opening drive and went for it on fourth and one, but Enoch Nawahine was stopped at the 1-yard line. The Cougars were 4 for 6 in the red zone, throwing an interception in the end zone in the third quarter.

Georgia Tech converted early, but ended the game 3 for 6 in the red zone, too. The Yellow Jackets fumbled the ball after a short catch in the third quarter at the 11-yard line. Aiden Birr’s 35-yard field goal late in the third quarter was blocked.

The game ended on a BYU interception in the end zone.

With a throw late in the second quarter, King set a Georgia Tech record for completions in a career. King finished his career with 676 completions in three seasons with the Yellow Jackets, passing Reggie Ball’s mark of 662 completions.

King also became the second player in Yellow Jackets’ history with 10,000 total yards, joining Joe Hamilton, who played at Georgia Tech from 1996-99 and tallied 10,640 yards.

King finished his career with 10,184 yards of total offense.

Georgia Tech: The Yellow Jackets ended a breakthrough season with Brent Key in disappointment, losing their final three games to miss out on the ACC championship game and College Football Playoff.

BYU: The Cougars scored another bowl victory and won their 12th game of the season, the first time BYU has won 12 games in a season since 2001.

Georgia Tech is to open its 2026 season at home against Colorado on Sept. 5.

BYU will open the 2026 season at home against Utah Tech on Sept. 5.

title: NFL playoff picture: How Broncos can clinch the AFC West and No. 1 seed in Week 17
description: Broncos. We break down how they can clinch the AFC West, and the No. 1 seed, in the 2026 NFL Playoffs in Week 17.
fullText:
Update (Saturday): The Broncos have clinched the AFC West title. The Chargers lost 20-16 to the Texans on Saturday, which officially clinched the division title for Denver. They could clinch the top seed with some more help on Sunday, but for now they’re guaranteed a top three seed in the 2026 NFL Playoffs.

Update (Christmas night): Denver’s win over the Chiefs on Christmas night keeps both of their scenarios alive for Week 17. The Broncos will clinch the AFC West with a Chargers loss or tie to the Texans on Saturday night. Denver can also clinch the No. 1 seed in the conference with a Patriots loss to the Jets, a Chargers loss or tie to the Texans, a Jaguars loss or tie against the Colts, and a Bills loss or tie against the Eagles.

The Denver Broncos travel to GEHA Field at Arrowhead Stadium on Christmas night to take on the Kansas City Chiefs.

And the Broncos can make it a wonderful Christmas for themselves and their fans with a win over their division rivals, and a little bit of help from around the rest of the league. Denver can clinch both the AFC West, and the No. 1 seed in the AFC, here in Week 17.

The Denver Broncos last won the AFC West back in 2015.

Peyton Manning — yes, the guy from the commercials — was their starting quarterback.

But Denver can clinch the AFC West title this week, officially bringing to an end the Kansas City Chiefs’ reign atop the division. With a win over the Chiefs on Christmas night, and a Los Angeles Chargers loss or tie against the Houston Texans on Saturday, the Broncos are AFC West champions.

Denver can also clinch the AFC West with a tie against the Chiefs, provided the Chargers lose to the Texans.

Not only can Denver clinch the AFC West this weekend, but the Broncos also have a narrow path to clinching the No. 1 seed in the AFC, something that again the team has not accomplished since that 2015 season.

However, Denver would need a lot of help to wrap that up this weekend.

First, the Broncos would need to win against the Chiefs on Thursday night. Then, the Broncos would need the New England Patriots to lose to the New York Jets, the Chargers to lose or tie against the Texans, the Jacksonville Jaguars to lose or tie against the Indianapolis Colts, and the Buffalo Bills to lose or tie against the Philadelphia Eagles.

So you’re saying there’s a chance …

x – Team has clinched a playoff spot
e – Team has been eliminated from playoff contention

title: Lakers 'recalibrate' after Austin Reaves injury, three-game losing streak
description: Coach JJ Redick said he calmly delivered a message to his players that it was time for "reconnection" with the team's second-leading scorer sideline at least a month.
fullText:
After the Lakers’ third straight loss Thursday, JJ Redick promised things would get “uncomfortable.” The second-year coach, frustrated after the team delivered a lump of coal in a Christmas Day blowout by the Houston Rockets, said he couldn’t stand to rewatch the same tired story. Leaning his elbow on the table at his postgame news conference, Redick called out players who don’t give enough effort on defense or play hard.

Two days later he stood in front of reporters with a different tone.

“Recalibration,” Redick said calmly of the message he delivered during Saturday’s team meeting. “Reconnection.”

Redick has cooled, but the Lakers still are under fire. Not only are they trying to snap a season-high three-game losing streak at home Sunday against the Sacramento Kings (6:30 p.m.), but also the Lakers (19-10) still are looking for their first home win in December and must navigate this defining moment without guard Austin Reaves.

Reaves was diagnosed with a grade 2 strain in his left calf Friday and will be reevaluated in four weeks. The latest setback comes less than two weeks after he was sidelined because of a “mild” strain in the same calf that kept him out for three games.

Reaves is averaging career highs in points (26.6), assists (6.3) and rebounds (5.2) and his ascent from undrafted rookie to potential first-time All-Star was one of the team’s feel-good stories of the season. Reaves scored a career-high 51 points against Sacramento in October, rescuing the Lakers in a game without LeBron James or Luka Doncic and showing Reaves’ potential in a starring role.

Now without their second-leading scorer, the Lakers are looking for their supporting cast to step up.

“We just need our guys to be stars in their roles,” Redick said. “Certainly from a top-end talent standpoint, it diminishes that. But it doesn't change the non-negotiables or how we're trying to play.”

After losing the last three games by an average of 20.7 points per game, the Lakers needed to get reacquainted with their non-negotiables during Saturday’s meeting. The session was uncomfortable in the way confronting truth can be uncomfortable, Redick said. It wasn’t just coaches lecturing, but also players speaking up.

The top priority was creating more clarity, Redick said. The team needed to get back to building its defensive fundamentals after so many lineup changes because of injuries. The Lakers have used 16 different starting lineups in 29 games and have to readjust their rotation again in Reaves’ absence.

“Togetherness is going to have to be emphasized to where it looks like an exaggeration,” center Deandre Ayton said, “where it becomes a habit. And that's what winners do. And it's pretty easy for this team. It's just that there's always a different group out there and we're going to get it for sure.”

Forward Rui Hachimura said coaches reminded players of the team’s three pillars that again were displayed on a screen in the practice gym Saturday — championship habits, championship communication, championship shape.

“We just talk about everybody, players, coaches, we just gotta kind of tighten up,” Hachimura said. “We had a good stretch in the beginning and now we kind of, I don't know, we relaxed or we kind of got tired of winning, you know, but we just stopped doing what we're supposed to do.”

The Lakers are 29th in the NBA in defensive rating in the last 15 games, giving up 122.2 points per 100 possessions. It’s a significant drop from their rating of 113.7 in the first 14 games in which they went 10-4.

Since James returned from, the Lakers’ preferred starting lineup — Doncic, Reaves, James, Ayton and Hachimura — has a net rating of minus-19.9 in seven games.

Offensively the Lakers have lacked organization since James came back, Redick acknowledged. James declined to speak to reporters after practice.

“Too many random possessions,” Redick said. “That's on me.”

This story originally appeared in Los Angeles Times.

title: Packers vs. Ravens Game Discussion: It’s a Backup Bowl on Saturday night
description: Join the Acme Packing Company community to discuss tonight’s big game between the Packers and Ravens!
fullText:
Sorry, NBC. For your late-season game streamed exclusively* on Peacock, you were expecting Jordan Love vs. Lamar Jackson with playoff implications. Instead, you’re getting Malik Willis vs. Tyler Huntley instead.

*Except in the Green Bay, Milwaukee, and Baltimore markets, which will get the game on local NBC stations.

To be sure, Willis vs. Huntley is pretty darn good as backup quarterback matchups go. Willis has been excellent for the Packers in the last two years when called upon to fill in for Love, while Huntley has been much the same as Jackson’s backup for five of the last six seasons. In fact, Huntley somehow even made a Pro Bowl in 2022, albeit as the sixth quarterback option for the AFC.

In any case, the game still has significant potential postseason implications for both of these teams. The losing team in this game will be eliminated from division contention with a loss, with Baltimore being eliminated from the playoffs outright if the Packers win. Green Bay is in the postseason already, but a loss locks them into the #7 seed instead.

Both teams still need considerable help to win their divisions, however, and even with a win could be knocked out with a single result going awry for them on Sunday.

Join us here at Acme Packing Company to discuss everything happening in and around tonight’s game!

title: FSU coaching changes tracker: Latest updates on Seminoles’ staff moves
description: The offseason is underway for Florida State, with changes to both the Seminoles’ roster and staff taking place over the coming weeks after a second-straight losing season. With an overhaul of the entire Florida State infrastructure having been proposed in last month’s announcement confirming the retention of head coach Mike Norvell, changes to the FSU […]
fullText:
The offseason is underway for Florida State, with changes to both the Seminoles’ roster and staff taking place over the coming weeks after a second-straight losing season.

With an overhaul of the entire Florida State infrastructure having been proposed in last month’s announcement confirming the retention of head coach Mike Norvell, changes to the FSU coaching staff have been underway, with the Seminoles having seen running backs coach David Johnson, quarterbacks coach Tony Tokarz and general manager Darrick Yray depart for jobs at other programs while defensive backs coach Pat Surtain Jr. was dismissed.

So far, FSU has hired a new running backs coach (Kam Martin), defensive ends coach (Nick Williams) and defensive backs coach (Blue Adams).

Last season, FSU hired six coaches to its staff — offensive coordinator Gus Malzahn, defensive coordinator Tony White, offensive line coach Herb Hand, safeties coach Evan Cooper, wide receivers coach Tim Harris Jr. and defensive line coach Terrance Knighton — with defensive ends coach John Papuchis moving to linebackers (while still retaining special teams duties) and longtime defensive tackle coach Odell Haggins retaining his associate head coach title but transitioning to an off-field role.

We’ll be tracking the changes as they come in, as well as any other news of note from the coaching staff.

December 27: FSU has hired John Garrett as its new general manager.

The Seminoles are hiring Taylor Edwards as Executive Director of Player Acquisitions.

December 18: After Brandon Harris opted to head to Gainesville, Florida State has found its new defensive backs coach in Blue Adams, who has served in the same role at Michigan State.

Florida State is promoting from within to replace Tony Tokarz, with assistant wide receivers coach Austin Tucker set to fill the role:

FSU grad assistant Ben Miles, son of Les, has been hired by Southern as its tight ends coach and recruiting coordinator:

Florida State graduate assistant Ben Miles is set to be hired as Marshall Faulk’s tight ends coach and recruiting coordinator at Southern, a source tells @CBSSports.

A return to Baton Rouge for the son of former LSU head coach Les Miles. Before FSU, he worked at Texas A&M. pic.twitter.com/nckVvaP3rr

— Matt Zenitz (@mzenitz) December 18, 2025

December 13: FSU quarterback coach Tony Tokarz is expected to become the offensive coordinator at Buffalo:

December 12: Brandon Harris has reportedly reversed course, with the UCF defensive backs coach expected to join Jon Sumrall’s inaugural staff at Florida:

December 11: FSU has made the hire of Nick Williams official:

“I’m thrilled to be joining the Florida State family,” Williams said. “I grew up watching Peter Warrick, Warrick Dunn, Charlie Ward and the aggressive, dominant defenses at FSU. As a South Georgia kid, you grow up wanting to be a Florida State Seminole. I remember going to Doak Campbell Stadium with my dad and how electrifying that experience was. My dad raised me that either you’re a liability or you’re an asset, and all I want to do is be an asset for Florida State. I get to come home and do what I love to do. You can’t ask for a better situation than that, and I’m looking forward to doing my part to help get Florida State back among the elite programs in America.”

General manager Darrick Yray is leaving to take the same position at UCLA:

title: Who is Malik Willis? Meet the failed Titans draft pick who has become impressive Packers backup
description: Who is Malik Willis? Meet the Green Bay Packers quarterback who went from a failed Tennessee Titans draft pick to a high-level backup in Green Bay.
fullText:
Who is Malik Willis? Meet the failed Titans draft pick who has become impressive Packers backup originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

The Green Bay Packers will square off against the Baltimore Ravens on Saturday in Week 17, and Matt LaFleur's squad will be without starting quarterback Jordan Love.

Love left the Packers' Week 16 defeat to the Chicago Bears early due to a concussion and was ruled out for Saturday's contest versus the Ravens. That means Malik Willis will take over as the starter for Green Bay.

Willis has made a few appearances for the Packers over the last two years, but let's get to know Green Bay's reliable backup quarterback.

Wills began his college career at Auburn, but transferred after just two seasons with the Tigers due to a lack of playing time. The dynamic signal-caller committed to Liberty, where he tossed 47 touchdowns and 18 interceptions with 27 scores on the ground as well.

After the 2021 season, Willis entered the 2022 NFL Draft and was selected in the third round by the Tennessee Titans.

Entering the league, Willis had a ton of hype around him, but his tenure with the Titans was short-lived and underwhelming. He spent just two years in Tennessee, making three starts and never throwing a touchdown pass.

After the 2024 preseason, where he showed improvement and promise, Willis was traded to the Packers to be Love's backup.

Though he wasn't expected to play a pivotal role, Willis was thrown into the fire during Weeks 2 and 3 of the 2024 season after Love went down with an injury. In those two starts, Willis dazzled, winning both games against the Indianapolis Colts and his former team, the Titans.

Willis finished the 2024 campaign with three touchdown passes, no interceptions, and a 74.1% completion rate. He also added a rushing touchdown.

So far in 2025, Willis hasn't made a start, but he's still played well when tasked to fill in for Love. The 26-year-old is now set for his first start of the season against the Ravens in a game Green Bay must win to stay alive in the NFC North division race.

title: Bears DE Austin Booker fined for two hits on Packers QB Jordan Love
description: Bears defensive end Austin Booker was fined by the NFL for his two illegal hits on Packers quarterback Jordan Love.
fullText:
The NFL has fined Chicago Bears defensive end Austin Booker for a couple of illegal hits on Green Bay Packers quarterback Jordan Love in last Saturday night's game, according to NFL Network's Tom Pelissero.

Booker was fined $11,636 total for his two hits on Love, including one that knocked Love out of the game with a concussion. It was the more controversial call of the two considering Love lowered his helmet to initiate helmet-to-helmet contact. But Booker was flagged, and now penalized, regardless.

When Love exited the game, the Bears defense struggled against backup quarterback Malik Willis, whose mobility proved to be an issue. But Chicago's bend-don't-break defense, coupled with quarterback Caleb Williams' fourth-quarter heroics, was able to pull off an improbable 22-16 overtime win.

Meanwhile, the NFL did not fine Packers cornerback Keisean Nixon for his late hit on wide receiver DJ Moore early in the first quarter. But Moore got the last laugh as he scored the game-winning touchdown in overtime with Nixon draped over him in the end zone.

Follow Bears Wire on Twitter, Facebook and Instagram

title: Chargers playoff picture: How loss to Texans impacts AFC wild-card race, LA's postseason chances
description: Los Angeles dropped to 11-5 after a Week 17 loss to the Texans, giving the Denver Broncos the AFC West title.
fullText:
Chargers playoff picture: How loss to Texans impacts AFC wild-card race, LA's postseason chances originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

The Los Angeles Chargers have emerged as a contender in a crowded AFC, but after a loss to the Houston Texans on Saturday, they can start packing their bags for their first playoff game.

Los Angeles dropped its Week 17 matchup against Houston, falling to 11-5 on the season and ceding the AFC West crown to the Denver Broncos, who had already clinched the division earlier in the week. The Chargers have secured a playoff spot for the second straight season, but will now do so as a wild-card team.

The loss to the Texans, who were fighting for their own playoff lives, locks the Chargers into a road game in the wild-card round, likely as the fifth or sixth seed in the AFC bracket. While Jim Harbaugh’s team entered Week 17 with a slim but viable chance to claim the coveted AFC West title and host a home game, the defeat eliminates that possibility and shifts the focus entirely to the final regular-season matchup.

Here’s where the Chargers stand in the AFC playoff picture.

NFL Week 17 picks against the spread

The Chargers have officially cemented their place in the postseason, but after the tough Week 17 loss to the Texans, the AFC West title is officially out of reach. That loss, which dropped the Chargers to second place in the division, means the Denver Broncos (13-3) have officially clinched the AFC West crown for the first time since 2015.

Jim Harbaugh's team will now shift its focus to securing the best possible Wild Card seed as they prepare for a road trip in the opening round of the playoffs. The Chargers now hold the tiebreaker for the top Wild Card spot over the 11-4 Buffalo Bills due to a better conference record, but Buffalo can take sole possession of that spot with a win over the Philadelphia Eagles on Sunday.

While winning the AFC West is no longer an option, the Chargers' Week 18 matchup against the division-champion Broncos remains critical. The outcome of that game will determine whether the Chargers can maintain their hold on the No. 5 seed or drop to the No. 6 seed, which would dictate their Wild Card opponent and likely a tougher travel schedule.

After securing their playoff ticket, the Chargers now focus on building momentum for the postseason, where they will try to make a run at the AFC Championship and the Super Bowl from the Wild Card position.

Currently, the Chargers sit at the No. 6 seed in the AFC.

With a win in Week 18, the Chargers would clinch at least the No. 6 seed. They need the Bills to lose to either the Eagles or the Jets to remain in the 5 seed.

Six of the seven teams in the AFC playoffs have clinched, with the AFC North spot being the one up in the air. The Bills can still catch the Patriots for the AFC East and the Texans can catch the Jacksonville Jaguars.

MORE: Meet Chargers QB Justin Herbert's family

title: Ortiz Makes AEW Return To Help Old Friend During Worlds End Zero Hour Pre-Show
description: Ortiz made his return to AEW during Zero Hour ahead of Worlds End to help out an old friend.
fullText:
Ortiz made his AEW return to run off the Grizzled Young Veterans following Zack Gibson's loss to Ortiz' old friend, Eddie Kingston, on the Zero Hour pre-show ahead of AEW Worlds End on Saturday. Gibson and James Drake beat up Kingston following the match, with Drake using his scarf to choke "The Mad King."

Before the tag team could do any more damage to Kingston, Ortiz ran down to the ring, armed with a loaded sock. He ran of GYV and stood tall with Kingston in the ring. Ortiz hasn't been seen on AEW programming since a match on "AEW Collision" at the beginning of 2024, when he and Kingston teamed up in a loss against Bryan Danielson and Claudio Castagnoli, then still known as the Blackpool Combat Club. Ortiz had been absent from the ring due to a torn pectoral muscle.

Ortiz wrestled in a dark match at "AEW Dynamite: Winter is Coming" on December 10, where he lost to HOOK. He took the "L" to the young star again during a Ring of Honor taping at the Hammerstein Ballroom last week. Ortiz had been working in backstage roles in AEW, such as coaching and producing, in his absence from TV.

title: Indianapolis Colts miss 2025 playoffs in rare fashion
description: The Indianapolis Colts have missed the 2025 playoffs in a very rare fashion.
fullText:
The Indianapolis Colts have been eliminated from the 2025 playoff race following the Houston Texans' win over the LA Chargers.

This is now the fifth consecutive year that the Colts have missed the postseason, and they did so in a way that has rarely been done before.

According to Josh Dubow of the AP, the Colts are just the sixth team in NFL history to start a season 8-2 and not make the playoffs.

The Colts join the 1995 Raiders, the 1993 Dolphins, the 1987 Chargers, the 1976 Bengals, and the 1976 Cardinals.

Along with the Colts' current playoff drought, Indianapolis also hasn't won the AFC South title since 2014.

Colts have gone from 8-2 to 8-7 and will be eliminated from playoff contention if Texans win today. Only teams since merger to miss playoffs after starting 8-2 or better:
1995 #Raiders 
1993 Dolphins
1987 Chargers (strike season)
1976 Bengals
1976 Cardinals

— Josh Dubow (@JoshDubowAP) December 27, 2025

The Colts have two games left in the season at this point, a home game in Week 17 against Jacksonville, followed by a road game in Houston to close out the year. But at the conclusion of the regular season, the Colts will enter another offseason filled with question marks.

GM Chris Ballard is in his ninth season at the helm, the Colts still have unknowns at quarterback, Shane Steichen's status will be up in the air, and Indianapolis is without a first-round pick in the next two drafts.

This article originally appeared on Colts Wire: Colts eliminated from 2025 playoffs in a rare way

title: Colts are sixth team since merger to start 7-1 and miss playoffs
description: The Texans' 20-16 win over the Chargers eliminated the Colts from playoff contention and made them the rare team to open a season 7-1 before failing to qualify for the postseason.
fullText:
The Texans' 20-16 win over the Chargers eliminated the Colts from playoff contention and made them the rare team to open a season 7-1 before failing to qualify for the postseason.

Only five other teams have suffered similar slides since the AFL-NFL merger and none of those teams have done it since the NFL moved to a 17-game season.

The Colts were able to get to 8-2, but they have lost their last five games heading into Sunday's game against the Jaguars. That collapse means they have now gone five straight seasons without a playoff berth.

Their last trip to the postseason came after the 2020 season. That was Philip Rivers' last full season in the NFL and the Colts coaxed the quarterback out of retirement a couple of weeks ago after Daniel Jones tore his Achilles. Rivers has played better than most people would have predicted, but the results haven't changed and the Colts will be left to ponder what might have been.

They'll also be left without their next two first-round picks to help shore up the roster. They sent both those selections to the Jets in a trade for cornerback Sauce Gardner and the first of those picks will be coming a lot earlier in the 2026 first round than originally anticipated as a result of the late season swoon in Indianapolis.

title: Why Reliability Demands Functional Programming
description: > In banking, telecom, and payments, reliability is not a nice to have. It is table stakes. The most reliable systems I have worked on reduce entire classes of bugs before the code even runs. Functional programming and Algebraic Data Types (ADTs) let you push correctness into the type system, so illegal states cannot be constructed in the first place. **What you will learn** - How invalid states show up in real systems and why they cause costly incidents - How ADTs encode business rules so the compiler enfo...
fullText:
In banking, telecom, and payments, reliability is not a nice to have. It is table stakes. The most reliable systems I have worked on reduce entire classes of bugs before the code even runs. Functional programming and Algebraic Data Types (ADTs) let you push correctness into the type system, so illegal states cannot be constructed in the first place.

Most production incidents are not due to complex algorithms. They are due to the code entering a state that should never have been possible. If you have been on call, you have seen variants of these:

Functional programming helps by modeling the domain with types that make invalid states unrepresentable. Pure functions and immutability keep behavior predictable and testable.

Product types combine fields, think "and". Sum types choose one of several cases, think "or". Together they model your domain rules.

With this shape, "paypal" cannot exist as a Payment. The compiler refuses the value.

When you pattern match on a sum type, the compiler can force you to handle every variant. If you later add a new case, every non exhaustive match becomes a compilation error or warning. This is how refactors become safe by default.

Add a new Crypto method and both code bases will point out every place you must update.

Incident story

A payout worker retries on network timeouts and calls settle() twice. The table allows pending = false and settled = true twice with the same ledger id. Reconciliation finds duplicates and accounting needs a manual fix.

Why it happened

State is spread across booleans and strings. The database does not express the lifecycle. The application code does, but only by convention and tests.

Transitions become total functions. You can return a Result when a transition is not allowed.

Now the illegal transitions are blocked by construction. Test coverage still matters, but the shape of the model prevents a class of bugs.

Refactor safety

When product adds Chargeback, the compiler highlights every match that ignores it. You cannot ship with a half handled lifecycle.

Every switch on TxnState now requires a chargeback branch. This is free guidance from the compiler.

Incident story

The call detail record pipeline generates billing events whenever it sees a Connected event. Under jitter and retries, some sessions never receive Completed. The billing system charges based on the wrong boundary and customers complain.

Why it happened

The call lifecycle is implicit across many services. A connected session with no end was still billable because there was no type that separated non billable states from billable ones.

Now a connected but never completed call cannot produce a billable duration. The shape forbids the bug.

Incident story

A cache TTL is stored in an environment variable. Someone sets CACHE_TTL_SECS=30s. In JavaScript, Number("30s") yields NaN and your code treats it as zero, disabling caching in production.

The ambiguity disappears. The code must handle absence and parse errors explicitly.

Do not use null to mean "maybe". Do not throw exceptions for expected errors.

These types make the happy path and the error path equally explicit.

Mutable shared state is a common source of heisenbugs under concurrency. Prefer immutable data and pure functions. When you need to update, create a new value.

Your tests become simple. Given the same inputs, the function returns the same output.

Numbers are not self describing. Create types that carry meaning.

You stop mixing milliseconds with seconds or dollars with cents by accident.

Keep the domain logic pure and push IO to the edges. This makes unit tests cheap and fast.

Start small and make continuous progress. Here is a practical order for a team new to these ideas.

Replace pairs of booleans with a sum type

Replace string enums with discriminated unions

Replace nullable fields with Option

Replace thrown control flow with Result

Introduce newtypes or branded types for units and ids

Pattern matching compiles to simple branches. Discriminated unions in TypeScript are just plain objects. The main cost you will feel is validation at the boundaries in smart constructors. This is a trade worth making. The compiler then protects the interior of the system.

Reliability is designed. With Algebraic Data Types, pattern matching, Option and Result, immutability, and smart constructors, you encode domain rules directly in your types. Illegal states cannot compile. This is why industries that cannot afford failure, such as banking and telecom, gravitate to functional ideas.

If you work on code that touches money, minutes, or public availability, adopt these patterns now.

Your on call shifts will be quieter, and your users will notice the difference.

title: Who Cares about the Baltic Jammer? Terrestrial Navigation in Baltic Sea Region [video]
description: Reports of GNSS interference in the Baltic Sea have become almost routine — airplanes losing GPS, ships drifting off course, and timing s...
fullText:
Lars,
Niklas Hehenkamp and
Markus

Reports of GNSS interference in the Baltic Sea have become almost routine — airplanes losing GPS, ships drifting off course, and timing systems failing. But what happens when a group of engineers decides to build a navigation system that simply *doesn’t care* about the jammer?

Since 2017, we’ve been developing **R-Mode**, a terrestrial navigation system that uses existing radio beacons and maritime infrastructure to provide independent positioning — no satellites needed. In this talk, we’ll share our journey from an obscure research project that “nobody needs” to a system now seen as crucial for resilience and sovereignty. Expect technical insights, field stories from ships in the Baltic, and reflections on what it means when a civilian backup system suddenly attracts military interest.

Since 2017, our team at DLR and partners across Europe have been working on an alternative to satellite navigation: **R-Mode**, a backup system based on terrestrial transmitters. Our main testbed spans the Baltic Sea — a region now infamous for GNSS jamming and spoofing.

We’ll start by showing what GNSS interference actually means in practice: aircraft losing navigation data, ships switching to manual control, and entire regions facing timing outages — such as the recent disruption of telecommunications in Gdańsk during Easter 2025.

Then we’ll take you behind the scenes of building R-Mode: designing signals that can coexist with legacy systems, installing transmitters along the coast, and testing shipborne receivers in rough conditions. We’ll share personal moments — like the first time we received a stable position fix in the middle of the Baltic.

Finally, we’ll talk about perception and politics: how a “research curiosity” became a critical infrastructure project, why ESA now wants to build a *satellite* backup (with the same vulnerabilities), and how it feels when your civilian open-source navigation system suddenly becomes strategically relevant.

Licensed to the public under http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0

This Talk was translated into multiple languages. The files available
for download contain all languages as separate audio-tracks. Most
